headline: Great company

cons: I don't have anything negative to say.

headline: Sales manager

cons: It is a sales and goal-driven environment which can be stressful for some.

headline: wachovia
pros: prior to acquisition was very good place to work
cons: Hard work goes un-noticed and promotions are based on who you know not quality of work.

headline: My Bank Teller Experience at Wachovia
pros: No evening shifts. Closed on Sundays. Excellent opportunity for young people. Good earning potential. Excellent training.
cons: This location required commuting through the DC Metro area. No or limited parking. Limited advancement opportunities.

headline: Banker
pros: excellent health benefit and work environment on going training competitive salary compare to other banks.
cons: horrible managers coworkers are not helping out each other don't really recommend to apply for this company

headline: Planning Analyst
pros: Very flexible hours, good bonus
cons: No overtime pay, no benefit

headline: Customer Service Person
pros: Great benefits, wonderful incentives, management works with employees to meet their goals. Good working hours, company believes in team participation to reach branch goals.
cons: High Pressure to make sales of new accounts, company quick to fire if quotas not met. Management does not backup employees or work to help them meet the company goals.

headline: Ok
pros: Good training classes and facility.
cons: No room to move up

headline: Associate
pros: senior managers were interested in what junior employees were working on
cons: large organization made quick decisions lengthy

headline: Sr. Compensation Consultant
pros: Strong employee culture with progressive HR policies

headline: great company
pros: I loved working for thios company. Greatest ever
cons: there were not a lot of cons. great company

headline: analyst
pros: Great place to work, good benefits
cons: moves slowly at times can can be frustrating

headline: Great place to work
pros: Awesome team setting with great support and recognition. Monthly team meetings for questions and concerns to be addressed. You get your own cubicle and could answer phones at your own pace, although there were incentives for meeting quotas.
cons: You get a lot of upset customers calling in and they can get pretty nasty over the phone without gave to face interactions. It can get very emotionally draining after awhile.

headline: This business teaches the importance of customer satisfaction.
pros: There is room for growth once you've proven yourself. The training prior to starting allows a buffer before interacting with clients.
cons: Relocation may be hard depending on the area. Salary is based on performance of the center and not on an individual basis.

headline: Wachovia
pros: Good atmosphere, good benefits, good salary
cons: Atmosphere changed for the worse after Wells Fargo took over

headline: Teller
pros: Coworkers and bank managers we're fun to work with. Handling cash isn't as easy as it looks and as a banker, you must be fully aware of fake bills and currency to protect the bank. Great way to get to know business owners and the community when you new to an area. I enjoyed working there.
cons: Regular cold calls to sell bank products was my least favorite part of the job. And banking hours in reality is not 9 to 5 like i thought. Days were longer than expected. I initially thought the hours would fit into a schedule that worked for my school age daughter.

headline: Aggressive Sales Tactics
pros: Good training program for new employees
cons: Overly aggressive sales strategy - no true customer relationship building; seems to be little concern for employees' interests; lots of praise for unethical employees who sell anything to any customer whether they need it or not.

headline: Employees cared for
pros: This was a bank that was all about customer service, not just sales as you find so often. The whole training was customer service based, what was right for THEM. Great benefits to employees including starting with 18 days of PTO.
cons: Low wages, hard to survive on the salary of a teller. Company was sold to Wells Fargo which is completely SALES based.

headline: FA
pros: Good growth opportunity to build a book
cons: Technology lacks behind other institutions

headline: Loan officer
pros: Positive focus on customer service
cons: Disjointed in approaches.. Too many different company cultures in one

headline: Watch who you work for
pros: Free lunch when funds come to the office. Nice people to work with.
cons: Cold calling, cold calling, and then more cold calling. Be careful which broker you work for.

headline: Great team
pros: Good location, a lot of incentives, opportunities for growth and good managers,severance pay and transfer opportunities
cons: High sales goals, our location was closed down and  a lot of people were laid off majority of transfers require sales .

headline: Collections Specialist
pros: This was a great job which paid well for the work that was required, as a College student.
cons: The job did require patience with dealing with people whom didn't like being called when they were behind on a payment.

headline: V.P. Regional Manager
pros: Balance between work and personal life is easily achieved at Wachovia.  There is long term tenure of employees, and a culture of customer service.
cons: Senior management often overlooks operational issues in lieu of sales.  It is also difficult to institute new processes.

headline: I miss this place.
pros: The people I worked with were fantastic. Great location, outstanding cafeteria, and the work kept us busy without giving us non-stop headaches. All in all, a wonderful place to work.
cons: None that I can think of right now.

headline: business director
pros: good benefits and people relationships were good
cons: changing incentive plan after the year began.

headline: Teller manager
pros: Great peers, nice incentives, and easy to understand products when it came time to sell. Location very close to home.
cons: heavy emphasis on selling, and no such thing as bankers' hours. Upper management gave lots of pressure for branch to meet its goals.

headline: Analyst
pros: Ample vacation time, good benefits, good people.
cons: Micromanagement as a virtue tough to swallow.

headline: Video Production Coordinator
pros: Great community minded company that treated employees fairly. Great for families and opportunities for advancement. Would have continued to stay there if not for re-structuring that came with Wells Fargo integration.
cons: Bad fiscal management, which led to the dismissal of our department. Well-intentioned company that tried hard to be great, but failed at actual banking. Had headquarters in Charlotte, which made communication with west coast challenging.

headline: Security Analyst
pros: Great Location, great facility, great career opportunities
cons: None, it is a great place.

headline: Manager
pros: Safe, polite work environment, decent pay
cons: Did not offer paid maternity leave

headline: Receptionist
pros: Pay was great and office culture was nice.
cons: It does not exist anymore.

headline: Property Manager
pros: Friendly and helpful management team.
cons: No benefits. Little training. No raises.

headline: Asst Client Manager
pros: fair, family oriented good work life balance, good benefits
cons: small company, little advancement in a small company, small bank mentality

headline: Financial Management
pros: Thought it was a great place to work
cons: Resource rightsizing due to M & A

headline: great
pros: Room for advancement, tuition reimbursement
cons: The collapse of Wachovia National Association

headline: Best company I ever worked for!
pros: Culture, great compensation package.  Wachovia culture was like family!  I enjoyed every day at work.  Lots of training and growth opportunities!
cons: Decisions could take a while.  The hiring process seemed to take forever and bureaucracy was rampant.

headline: Great experiance , Great people
pros: great work life balance
cons: Pay is often sub market

headline: Good entry level; something to put experience on your resume
pros: Sometimes casual environment. Usually friendly coworkers
cons: Cant leave your desk to go to the bathroom. Its like elementary school.

headline: Good employer
pros: Good wages and opportunities. Great upper management
cons: Downsizing. Company can be too large.

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Compensation was great, good job atmosphere
cons: Long hours and somewhat disfunctional branches

headline: Great company. Would have likely never left if the brokerage's HQ hadn't moved to STL.
pros: Great co-workers. Young,  outgoing and fun workforce that had balanced lives and made being at work feel less like a "job."
cons: 20 word minimum. 20 word minimum.20 word minimum. 20 word minimum. 20 word minimum. 20 word minimum. 20 word minimum.

headline: Best banking comp plan
pros: Comp plan, sales does not report to branch manager, provide tools to succeed and exceptional training, allow employees to easily transfer between departments.
cons: Work life balance, have to work occasional weekends, went out of business, not flexible considering improvements that can be made to current processes

headline: Wachovia
pros: Health benefits, work life balance, office culture was great! Compensation was in line with role specifications. Worked in a centralized unit and processes were well defined?
cons: I really enjoyed my time here and do not have any cons to note. Departed from the company only because husband job transferred to another city.

headline: Best bank to work for
pros: very good company that takes care of their employees
cons: banking industry is very challenging and stressful

headline: Customer servce
pros: Great Pay, Great Benefits, Great Team Leads
cons: Stressful Job, easy to get fired, very hard to earn incentives

headline: Friendly overall atmosphere
pros: Friendly supervisors and staff. My team always made sure everyone was acknowledged during birthdays, etc.
cons: There isn't much that pops into my mind.

headline: Great Company
pros: Great pay policy which treat employees fairly.  Switch to Wells fargo was the wost thing that happened.  Good work life balance.
cons: The switch to wells fargo stalled all chances of advancement and promotion.  It became all about churning out numbers and selling products people didnt need.

headline: good customer service excellent computer skills sales and a solution to the problem. Good advice.
pros: meeting people and helping find a solution to there banking needs, puting a smile on customers face. very competitive person. willing to work the othe individual.
cons: geting to find how to increase new numbers each week set myself apart from the rest of the lersonal bankers

headline: Excellent working teams
pros: Great culture and satifying work
cons: Poor visibility into long term strategy

headline: I learned a lot about mortgage time frames and the over whelming state of the economy.
pros: Well know it Wells Fargo but, it's one of the top banks in the country so, there are great benefits, pay and long lasting friendships.
cons: I don't have any cons really about this company.

headline: VP, Manager of Sourcing
pros: Work/life balance, good benefits. time-off policies
cons: good old boy system, limited growth

headline: Nice and knowledgeable co-workers.
pros: They provided good training. I worked in a busy branch so it was a fast-paced environment. I liked it because it was never boring and the day flew by.
cons: Teller manager was not flexible with scheduling. It was a mission to schedule doctor appointments. Progressing in the company was not an easy thing to accomplish.

headline: Hard On Selling, but Generally a Nice Place to Work
pros: Decent pay and benefits, even for part-time work. GREAT teller training. Recognition for doing great. They put an emphasis on creating a good environment for customers, which I appreciated as a teller as it made my job pleasant.
cons: Expectations varied from branch to branch (I worked at one where the entire team was general happy to be there because of the great management, clear expectations, and generally smooth running of things; the second branch I worked at was the complete opposite, which eventually led me to leave the company). A little too much emphasis on selling products sometimes--especially as Wells Fargo was taking over;

headline: Great company
pros: Great company to work of
cons: Acquisition by first union changed the company

headline: Popularity contest in Derivative Operations
pros: Willing to pay for external talent...Charlotte is an excellent city to live in.  Good place to work if learning and not interested in promotion or questioning policies/processes/procedures.  Plenty of good people, unfortunately they are not in management.
cons: Very difficult to promote/transfer internally for high level performers.  High level will often be kept in their current position and not allowed chances to grow or change.  Less talented employees who focus on popularity contests are more easily promoted and then re-shuffled when they fail.  Ethics are not highly regarded and mgmt shows no interest in generating a positive work atmosphere.  Highly ethical individuals might become uncomfortable over time.

headline: Great place to work until Wells Fargo came with their horrible leadership!
pros: Co-workers were like family.Training was excellent.....Wells Fargo training methods were a joke...
cons: Typical corporate.....No perks!......Wells Fargo Training Style AKA which way is the wind blowing!

headline: Was a great company, sorry to see it gone.
pros: Customer service was the best in the country.
cons: It was hard to advance career.

headline: Loved working here! (call center)
pros: Was great place to work when it was Wachovia! I will rate below based on Wachovia.
cons: When they became Wells Fargo it took a turn for the worse. Everyone was unhappy employees and customers. The company stopped caring about the customer and only cared about the almighty dollar. Overworked, disrespected and unappreciated their employees. (sad)

headline: Great experience working in firm on brokerage side of the house
pros: Good corporate culture. although you can get overlooked as a low producer. emphasis on higher income producers. these producers would get higher percentage payouts.
cons: sold to wells fargo. did not allow for a share holder vote. in the quarterly report before the firm was stating they would go bankrupt, wachovia stated the firm was in a strong financial position.

headline: Great Company To Work For
pros: Able to learn about multiple functions
cons: Being in the location that I was in, the atmosphere was slow.

headline: Wonderful Place to Work
pros: Great benefits, I loved the people I worked with. Little sales pressures,
cons: Technology was outdated so I felt frustrated at times

headline: Legal
pros: Wachovia was very committed to work-life balance.  Offered a great benefits package, generous vacation, sick days, family care time, and time to participate in charitable events.  Was a great place to work.
cons: Too many management layers and very tight budgets.

headline: sad
pros: over time pay was good
cons: had to keep selling to get good reviews

headline: Wachovia good company
pros: Great company that cared for its employees
cons: sold to another bank that didn't value the employees

headline: Product pushing disguised as financial consulting! Its product of the week city!
pros: If you are in the right branch with affluent customers, you are golden. Pay is competitive, health benefits great.
cons: If you ever need to take a day off with less than two weeks notice, don't think about it.

headline: Gone but not forgotten
pros: There was a strong community of bankers.
cons: Now Wells Fargo with a different culture.

headline: Great place to work.  Love my co workers
pros: Location was great. about 10 minutes from my home
cons: Traffic was terrible.  There was a bottleneck getting into the site.

headline: Ugh
pros: Enjoyed the people I worked with
cons: Terrible culture-micro management to a T

headline: I miss this company
pros: Everything was cool. Nice People nice place to work. Good training.
cons: Nothing it was a great company to work for, too bad it no longer exists

headline: Wachovia assigned me to the Mainframe priviledge access administration position.
pros: Loved working for Wachovia was disappointed when Well's fargo obtained them.
cons: Well's fargo did not merge most current Wachovia employee's

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great atmosphere to work in while in Richmond VA, the team leads, managers and superiors actually cared about their associates. Great team atmosphere. The company relocated in 2008 but that wasnt an option in the drop down.
cons: Once the company merged with Wells Fargo and relocated to St. Louis the atmosphere there was different. The open door policy that existed in Richmond at Wachovia didnt exist in St. Louis at Wells Fargo with the managers.

headline: I certainly wish circumstances were different and my career still with this company
pros: They support further advancement and while not everyone received respectible compensation I know that I did. The benefits package was outstanding and many selections that I certainly took advantage of while there.
cons: Too many disconnected upper managment staff. They really have and had no understanding of what was happening in the lower ranks. Therefore had no idea how to motivate and keep them engaged. The culture was very much an us versus them mentality because while upper management thought they were doing a great job in reality they did nothing but alienate the people the worked for them.

headline: Positive
pros: The people and work environment
cons: Worked in a very tough regulatory environment

headline: 10 years until Wells Fargo Acquisition ended my career
pros: flexible work environment, great pay, advancement opportunities
cons: Acquired by Wells Fargo in 2009

headline: Absolute politics at its worst... Internally, the company is so divided that it doesn't know which direction to go.
pros: They knowledgable people but they are all too scared of getting their heads chopped off
cons: They will throw you under the bus in a heartbeat.

headline: One of the Best Companies I ever worked for
pros: Work life Balance outstanding, training program one of the best in Retail sector.
cons: Was bought out by Wells Fargo and then all matrix changed within the corporation

headline: Used to not be awful...USED to
pros: decent salary and benefits program.
cons: sharks in the water...will suck your soul out and drain you of all dignity.

headline: The people were fun.
pros: The pay was always great.
cons: The atmosphere some days were a bit boring.

headline: Overall it was O.K..  It seems that they like their employees to stay in the same role for extended periods of time.
pros: Great group of people to work with.  Overall I was satisified with the work and what was required of me.
cons: Did not really seems like anyone was interested in promoting me or helping me advance my career.  Was told that they knew I was being paid a below market salary - but if I wanted an increase to market rate I would need to get another job offer.  Then we could discuss the possibility of an increase.  Funny thing is I actually did that - but then took the other job resluting in a 40% salary increase.

headline: nice while it lasted
pros: Great training and personal growth
cons: it was a great job while it lasted but the industry bottomed out and we were let go in a large group of 7k.

headline: Division Manager
pros: Work/Life balance was highly recognized.  Management listened to suggestions for improvement.
cons: Lower level management would sometimes micro-manage.

headline: Very professional company.
pros: Great training and development of staff
cons: No longer around. Wells Fargo acquired them.

headline: great company that cared about its people
pros: always gave time off and very understanding
cons: changed to wells fargo and now sales is the most important

headline: Great experience
pros: Pay, flexible hours, co workers
cons: Supervisor out of state, trouble getting questions answered.

headline: Mismanagement of Employees
pros: Provided position for initiation and development successful career as financial professional.
cons:
Advancement and tenure of Financial Specialist leading district in most categories of performance review was limited by mismanagement and micro-management of very young and inexperienced manager, no longer employed by Wachovia. Employees in comparable banking positions are shocked by the reasons for which I was written up: 1. Followed instructions of telephone to support customer by replacing single checking account rather than taking extended time to reconfigure initial terms (at time the only representative serving extensive line of customers). 2. Initialized, but immediately canceled before transacting, wire transfer requested by telephone by customer claiming to need funds for medical emergency; 3. Misplaced - but later relocated - deposit slip for new CD. 4. Opened checking account for customer with temporary license (account was opened with cash deposit, no withdraw allowed for funds beyond initial cash deposit until presentation of permanent license.
Notes on U-5/U-5 have virtually ruined career opportunities of highly professional who did no violation of ethics & who provided consistently excellent service for clients.

headline: I enjoyed working in the Item Processing Dept
pros: Excellent benefits and the supervisors were very professional and caring.
cons: Everyone on the team did not do their part.

headline: Great Company that Valued Human Capital
pros: Wachovia really valued its employees. Appreciated the 360 review process. Would go back to work for the bank in a heartbeat. Compensated employees well. Even as an Admin i was encouraged to take ownership of my job and learn as much about the business my group did.
cons: Some of the Wachovia culture has been lost with the change to Wells Fargo but from what I know Wells is still a great company to work for.

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
Great work/life balance
Decent Salary compared to other banks
cons:
Saturdays
Having to work some holidays that other banks are closed

headline: Good People, But Not the Pay
pros: I worked with a lot of great people. The was a real sense of comradaraie. People worked hard during the day and had lots of fun together after work.
cons: The pay was horrible and there were major descrepencies among colleagues. Management work take advatange of anyone they could.

headline: Corporate Corporate Corporate
pros: If you are interested in playing the political games it takes to be successful, then this comapny is very rewarding and has plenty of opportunities for growth and advancement. They do pay well and will offer wonderful benefits
cons: Cross the wrong person in this company and your longevity will be non existent. They expect the highest quality work with some of the most antiquated systems and for the most part can deliver.

headline: 3.5yrs as FCM
pros: Great internal and external culture of service.
cons: Poor senior leadership. Pure greed by senior executives led to bad decisions and ultimately the collapse of the organization. Wells Fargo culture is about money, not service.

headline: Best place I ever worked
pros: Always looking to promote and train. Senior staff knew you by your full name and actually remembered you. Friendly coworkers. Top business for Customer Service by far!!! Started out in the flagship in Rockefeller in New York. Miss you Wachovia!!!
cons: No longer around, Wells Fargo now

headline: Item Processor
pros: Would like to obtain discounts just by working with Wachovia
cons: Managers wouldn't upgrade employees nor would they assist in helping employees improve their abilities

headline: Was one of the best places to work in North Carolina
pros:
Extremely competent coworkers
Sense of community among teams
Challenging work
Recognition of achievements
cons: Near the end, everything changed and it became a stressful place to work.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great atmosphere and a lot room for growth
cons: Hire a lot of temps

headline: Wachovia Review
pros: Great company to work for with many opportunities.
cons: Mortgage was the banks downfall

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Flexible hours, career growth from within, competitive salary.
cons: The instability of working in the banking industry.

headline: Wachovia was my life and I loved it
pros: Great Training, great benefits, felt valued
cons: Call nights for existing and/or non clients

headline: Too Long
pros: Good benefits, regular hours. Other than that, not much.
cons: No room for creativity in the least. If you do well, they make it more difficult for you until you can't do well.

headline: Management needs lots of work
pros: Great environment, lots of young professionals, room for growth if you are interested.
cons: Teller staff is never more than two people at the window sometime one person until 10 am. Lots of favoritism, unorganized management.

headline: great
pros: the comp was very caring ...
cons: needed to open more jobs

headline: Former World Savings employee.
pros: There was a big focus on employee training and development for all levels, excellent execution of corporate strategies to the branch with organization and attention to detail, and I feel we maintained integrity while gaining the business from our customers.
cons: There was a very big company feel and a loss of individual office personality; everything was micromanaged and even the management styles were no longer allowed to be autonomous in the branches. The computer systems were also far behind in technology and not user friendly primarily due to the previous acquisitions. And the health benefits were very expensive.

headline: Great Experience
pros: Competitve pay, flexible hours, nice incentive plan with no cap. Management expressed expectations and employees were always in alignment with company goals.
cons: Wells Fargo endorsed the Pick a Pay Mortgage which ultimately led to their downfall. There were not very many positions outside of the actually branch, so growth was limited.

headline: not too satisfied with banking opportunities
pros: good hours, training was significant for learning credit analysis skills and portfolio analysis. Flexible benefits and good team of co-workers made this an enjoyable place to work
cons: no access to upper level management, most corporate development programs were based in North Carolina. Big bank type culture with no room for growth.

headline: Personal Banker
pros: Fantastic company to work for.  Lots of great mentors available to help you learn the ropes and move up in the company.
cons: As with any sales position, the pressure to meet goals can be intense at times.

headline: Personal Banker
pros: it had a good work environment, and managers and a good work life balance good training and happy employes
cons: But then it turned bad as soon as we were bought by wells fargo, it was all results all the time or you were punished and taken away from your family.

headline: Sorry to see Wachovia go!
pros: Fair incentive programs in sales and service.
cons: Wells Fargo bought them out.

headline: Good and bad
pros: Benefits 401k bonuses insurance good customer service
cons: Hardcore goals too much pressure

headline: Too bad they are gone
pros: Family care time, decent benefits
cons: No longer exists exists because of wells fargo

headline: very nice
pros: senior management really cared about their employees
cons: merger or take over by wells fargo

headline: Great Bank
pros: Benefits, Time off, Great Leaders
cons: Sitting at desk in front of center

headline: Wachovia
pros: Was a great place to work.
cons: Sometimes like the federal government in terms of process.

headline: At your own risk
pros: I don't have any to share
cons: This was not the right culture for me. Wrong place, wrong time. I was miserable there

headline: Wachovia bank teller job full time
pros: full time, steady pay check
cons: low pay and long hours

headline: generally good, upbeat work environment, at least within my group
cons:
not very exciting.
big company, slow movement

headline: Private Banking Relationship Manager
pros: Systems and products were strong. Benefits were good
cons: Bureaucracy, Getting things done was difficult. Mediocracy was celebrated.

headline: Wachovia was great, Wells Fargo was not
pros: I had a great boss, then she went to a competing company.
cons: Wells Fargo's way of doing things was very different from Wachovia.  Wachovia cared about their customers and employees, WF has pushed their employees to sell, sell, sell.  You will be fired if you do not hit your sales numbers forcing employees to sell things to customers that they don't need so they can hit their numbers and keep their job.  Sad.

headline: Loan Origination District Manager
pros: Good benefits package, great earning potential
cons: lending strategies changed often and emphasis on products moved all over the board

headline: Great Department
pros: The benefits were great and loved the people I worked with.  And interaction with customers/cliens.
cons: Parking for work because of being downtown.

headline: Fine place to work at in NC
pros: Good pay for the work load
cons: Too big to fail worked here too!

headline: Overall bad experience
pros: Nothing really comes to mind.  The only good part about working there were a few great coworkers.
cons: There wasn't any sense of employee appreciation, you felt like you were just another number.  Very bureaucratic atmosphere.  The management was inconsistent and overall poorly run.

headline: Teller
pros: Nice people within the branch. Federal holidays off. You really get to know the customers.
cons: Too much micromanaging from external managers. I worked in Houston and had to email someone from dallas to get a day off. Upper level managers constantly would start trouble in the branches. Sales credits are hard to make when you are part time.

headline: Financial Center Manager
pros: Not a whole lot, used to be good until it was taken over by Wells Fargo.  Now the hours are too long and and pay is less.
cons: Too much boy's club.   Management didn't really care about employee wells being and insensitive to changes.

headline: All in all, positive
pros: When Wachovia was Wachovia (post First Union merger, that is), we were making strong efforts to make our technology purchases smart, to make projects accountable for their costs, and the like.
cons: Upper management lost focus on the core business and chased the buck all the way into the near collapse of the company, culminating in the Wells Fargo buyout.  A sad epitaph.

headline: A lot of areas to advance if your willing to change
pros: Flexible time schedule for employees.
cons: Upper management is blind sometimes

headline: Great Company, new ownership just as good
pros: Sales experience, compensation potential, can move up pretty quick with good numbers
cons: Not the most exciting industry

headline: Great Place to work at
pros: Wachovia was a big bank with a small bank feel. Great work environment, very good compensation and excellent systems. Good growth opportunities. Management was conservative but that  is what made the bank stronger, and reduced volatility in employment. Steady place to work in.
cons: Branch offices felt left out of the loop and excluded from goings  on in Charlotte. Management in Charlotte was not able to comprehend work environments and cost structure in areas like new York.

headline: Great company but gone...
pros: Wachovia was a good company to work for.  It was big enough to offer plenty of opportunities but not too big to be impersonal.
cons: It was sold in a fire sale...

headline: financial center manager
pros: good benefits, training, location, exposure
cons: no balance personal life/work , internal politics, favoritism, lack of support, difficult to get promotion, high volume turn over, no employer interest to keep and develop employee

headline: For a Fortune 500 company it was very poorly run
pros: Good compensation and working conditions
cons: A very disorganized quagmire of bureaucracy managed by overwhelmingly arrogant and self righteous people at the top.

headline: Ok beginner job.
pros: It was nice to be making double digits per hour. Also nice to receive balancing incentives and other perks like "banker's hours".
cons: The sales pressure wasn't emphasized until months after obtaining the position.

headline: Large and beauracratc
pros: Good opportunity for broad range of skills and background;  Open and tolerant of different backgrouds and cultures in certain positions.  Compensatyion lower to mid range for most positions   A company this large is full of change  and opportunity but not a place to build along term career  after 5 or so years move on.
cons: compensation under constant annual modification and review  Metrix driven bonus and commissions are always extremely demanding and designed to be very very difficult to achieve.  Almost impossible to recieve above avg ratings such as  "meet and exceed". Performance reviews are very tough and even unfair  and forget about "discussing or changing"  no such thing.   You will be part of the CYBOG

headline: Working at Wachovia was great. It is Wells Fargo now.
pros: Wachovia employees had a sense of family, lots of charitable work off site like Habitat for Humanity and other team building activities so you could get to know other employees in other areas of the company who did your exact job function. It was an excellent networking opportunity.
cons: From what I hear now since the Wells Fargo take over, that sense of community "family" is gone and the emphasis is on "production, production, production, and service scores".

headline: Tenure at Wachovia
pros: Was part of big merger, thank goodness our previous company had better severance packages and made sure we received it.
cons: Didn't know what they were doing in the wholesale mortgage business

headline: Tedious part time work for the benefits
pros: Received full benefits working only 20 hours a week. Proper training is provided to all new hires.  Flexible with vacation requests.
cons: Doesn't seem like there is room to grow within the company. After working 5 years and establishing myself as a valuable employee, management would still not give me the opportunity to advance after several job positions opened.

headline: Customer Service Rep
pros: Excellent Team, Good Pay, sShift diff pay
cons: Shift Changes, Usually start on second shift.

headline: Amazing company that promotes from within.
pros: Promotes from within. Lots of growth opportunity
cons:
No longer exists ... went under
Year wait to post unless exceptions were made.

headline: A stepping stone
pros: The various bank holidays is always a plus
cons: Depending on what department you were hired into there was no room for growth or development.

headline: Good company while it lasted.
pros: Very good.   Lot's of opportunity for promotions were available.
cons: Poor lending decisions led to company downfall.

headline: Awesome company, but at the end a let down
pros: Excellent training, solid company to work for
cons: At local level, product pushing

headline: Wachovia before Wells Fargo merger
pros:
Huge bank with many different departments and ability to transfer.
Recognize success
cons: Goals were SUPER STRETCH goals but we were expected to reach them every month.

headline: a good place to work
pros: lots of opportunities there to learn new stuffs, generous relocation packages, good office environment, nice boss and coworkers
cons: the sad thing is they did bad in financial crisis, and was taken over by wells fargo

headline: Teller
pros: Great benefits, family oriented and fast promotion
cons: Company merged with Wells Fargo. Alot of new changes

headline: Better before Wells Fargo rolled in
pros: Worked with come nice people.  They deserved to be treated  better
cons: Too much micro managment and reporting

headline: A good place to be for the long haul
pros: A very family-like place to work, where people can contribute across department, or even across business, lines.
cons: Career progression was almost frowned upon. Management tended to expect employees to be so happy in their current position that an employee was expected to never want to leave that team or department (or the company).

headline: Good culture, smart colleagues, generally satisfied
pros:
- they have a friendly and serious culture
- worked with smart colleagues
- i received solid, market level pay
- the work environment was typically very intellectually challenging
cons:
- i frequently worked for long hours and on several weekends
- quite often, i was staffed on projects that required me to do time consuming, yet mundane and boring tasks, like update powerpoint slides or enter data into excel models

headline: Good place to start
pros: Good place to get your Series 7 and break into the industry.
cons:
Churn and and burn um philosophy when it comes to new recruits.  
Lack of mentorship.
High account fees makes it difficult to attract and grow clients.

headline: Overall a very solid professional experience
pros: The talent level across the board was pretty strong. Open to new ideas and spirited private debate.  Provided development opportunities.
cons: A bit slow at times due to too many layers.

headline: Good learning experience that explained how much stress I was capable of handling at once.
pros: The paid-time-off, friendly coworkers, and great managers.
cons: The policies, inflexible hours, sales-pushiness, stress for lack of staffing, and no proper on-site training development for beginners.

headline: was great, then had no direction/vision from the top-down
pros: benefits, good people to work around. the legacy employees were great and were proud to be there
cons: culture suffered after a string of acquisitions

headline: Great place to work (used to be anyway)
pros: Great place to work when it was Wachovia. Not sure now that it's been bought by Wells Fargo. Laid back environment for an Investment Bank. If you're in the investment banking section, you still get comparable compensation as other Wall Street firms, working in a city (Charlotte) with low cost of living. A lot of new business to get involved when I was there back in 2005 to 2008.
cons: Made serious mistakes in mortgage business but you all know that. Maybe it was too eager to imitate other Wall Street firms instead of sticking to its strength.

headline: Overall good experience.
pros: Good pay and benefits compared to other trust companies in the area.
cons: Poor middle management in the area.

headline: Great advancement opportunities.
pros: Job advancements, promotions, compensation, excellent management, excellent deal flow.
cons: Spintered business units, difficult to navigate IT systems, bank still lacks integration with other business units.

headline: just "okay"
pros: Probably the only thing I really liked about working there is that no matter what they did, they always put the customers first. They highly reccommend you get to know the customers, and are concern about them. I have always conversated with my customers and they wouldn't mind because they want to help their customers. A+ for customer service and satisfaction.
cons: They were just really hard to work around their own employee's schedule and important personal leaves/unavaliablity due to school and such. As a full-time college student, they made me write a written statement, just stating that I chose school over working. (Like, c'om seriously?).  They litterally sat me down to pick out my school schedule for me.  Instead, I just turned in a written two weeks notice.

headline: I loved Wachovia it was a great place to work.
pros: Great professional atmosphere, environment was conducive to learning and growing.
cons: It was acquired by another bank.

headline: a good independent way to make a living. nothing will be handed to you
pros: independence, ability to structure your business and your day as you see fit
cons: it's all up to you

headline: Great place to work
pros: Good benefits, medical , dental, vision, 401 k with matching employer contribution up to 6 %. A good team friendly atmosphere
cons: The hours that you are required to work including Saturday. The time required to be on the phonetaking calls and complete other duties

headline: Does not offer career progression
pros: casual environment and fair package.
cons: no career progression or prospect within the company

headline: Able to get a good customer service experience
pros: Interaction with people and sales experience..
cons: Salary was low and with no opportunity for advancement

headline: The best company that cares about employees
pros: Great benefits for their employees
cons: Merger pushed it to Wells.....mean people. Working with wells be prepared for them to use you then leave you in the cold

headline: I am very proud to have worked with a great team for a great company
pros: They opportunity for advancement and thier benefits package
cons: I regret that our company closed our office after merger with wells fargo bank

headline: ridiculous
pros: loyal customer base makes coming to work enjoyable
cons: no recognition. goals are floating constantly. in other words you are assigned your goal, however pushed to achieve 150% of goal. If not trending towards the floating goal you are punished and made to stay until 7 or 8 pm

headline: Not a bad place, not a great experience
pros: Opportunity for advancement, many departments.
cons: Many barriers to knowledge sharing.

headline: A frustrating experience.  Sell product first, sell more product second and kick problems down the road for others.
pros:
For a sales position, if/when all the incentives and team goals aligned, you could be paid very well.

The immediate supervisors I had were great teachers of the position.
cons:
The commitment to customer service was ostensibly driven by employees who are experts in working with clients but it was more about working the system.

If you have any hesitation about selling a financial product, this is not the position for you.  Before 2008, the focus was understanding your customer, knowing their goals and objectives and then matching those needs to a product.  That changed as the banking environment deteriorated to using double-talk to sell product first, grabbing customers, and worrying later about the connection to their financial situation.

The technology in the branches was terrible.  Very old computers and software made things painfully slow.

headline: Great company for employees, at least before the take over
pros:
Employee friendly
easy work from home
cons: do not have strong institutional clients

headline: I really enjoyed my time at Wachovia.  It was an excellent company to work for.
pros: Wachovia encourage training and development and owning your own career. Leadership was very engaged and 'walked the talk'.  They were head & shoulders above their competition in the area of Diversity. Human Resources truly partnered witht he business to create a strong ethical and healthy corporate culture.
cons: It's unfortunate the they were bought out by Wells Fargo.  Well Fargo is WAY behind in the area of workforce diversity.  Senior Management is primarily made up of "old white men"!!!!  To remain competitive and retain a cutting edge workforce, Well Fargo will need to make some MAJOR changes.

headline: well paid
pros: pay and benefits were good
cons: Lots of turf control. You couldn't do anything without first checking with 10 other people

headline: Sales sales sales
pros: benefits are competitive and fairly good
cons: pay below average when compared with competitors

headline: Good
pros: Good training available for all jobs.
cons: High stress on employees not good.

headline: In the Middle
pros: They offered  entry level Great Training
cons: No work life balance made it diffult on the family

headline: Meaningful
pros: Analytical, Intense, Thoughtful, well paid
cons: Less Caring, non meritocracy, clubby
